Sum time values

Source: R/sum_time.R
sum_time.Rd

sum_time() returns the sum of the time from different kinds of date/time objects. The sum can also be set to roll on a 24 hours clock basis, helping with time arithmetic issues.

sum_time(..., class = "hms", clock = TRUE)

Arguments

...

Vectors belonging to one or more of the following classes: Duration, Period, difftime, hms, POSIXct, POSIXlt, or Interval.
class

(optional) A string indicating the output class (default: "hms").
clock

(optional) A logical value indicating whether the sum should roll over on a 24 hour clock basis (default: TRUE).

Value

If clock = TRUE (default), an object of the indicated class in class (default: "hms") with the sum of the time from objects in ... rolled over on a 24 hour clock basis. Else, the same as previous, but not rolled over on a 24 hours clock basis (accumulative).

Details

class argument

sum_time() is integrated with convert_to(). That way you can choose what class of object will prefer for output.

POSIXt objects

POSIXt values in ... will be strip of their dates. Only the hours will be considered.

Period objects

Period objects are a special time of object develop by the lubridate::lubridate team that track changes in clock times ignoring time irregularities. That is to say that 1 day as Period will always represent 1 day in the time line.

sum_time ignores that property of Period objects, treating them as objects of class Duration.

Time line irregularities

This function does not take into account time line irregularities (e.g. leap years, DST, leap seconds). This may not be a issue for most people, but it must be considered when doing time arithmetic.

See also

Other time arithmetic functions: assign_date(), shortest_interval()

Examples

sum_time(hms::parse_hm("11:45"), lubridate::dhours(5))

#> 16:45:00
#> 16:45:00 # Expected
sum_time(lubridate::hours(25), lubridate::dhours(5), lubridate::minutes(50))

#> 06:50:00
#> 06:50:00 # Expected
sum_time(lubridate::days(), lubridate::dhours(8), clock = FALSE)

#> 32:00:00
#> 32:00:00 # Expected
x <- c(as.POSIXct("2020-01-01 15:00:00"), as.POSIXct("1999-05-04 17:30:00"))
y <- lubridate::as.interval(lubridate::dhours(7), as.Date("1970-05-08"))
sum_time(x, y, clock = FALSE, class = "duration")

#> [1] "142200s (~1.65 days)"
#> [1] "142200s (~1.65 days)" # Expected
